text: thank you thank you everyone for coming
thank you Laura for the introduction and
to David and Robert for inviting me to
be part of this panel I'm very excited
to be here to have a chance to offer
this presentation particularly because I
almost did not make it since Southwest
canceled my flight Wednesday night
so as Laura mentioned I intended for
this to be part of the opening session
to set a context for the importance and
the reasons and rationales for doing
race research but I think after hearing
the sessions yesterday afternoon and
this morning
it actually fits well for offering a bit
of a summation and closing to offer some
examples of research that tie together a
lot of the things that we've heard about
and also offer specific data to buttress
the points that many of the previous
speakers have made so I'll just start
with the title of the presentation the
persistent problem of the color-line
researching race in the 21st century and
as I'm sure most if not all of you
recognize the title of the presentation
is a pretty obvious nod to the work of
sociologist WB Dubois who wrote in the
early 20th century that the problem of
the 20th century will be the problem of
the color line and in a lot of Du Bois
is prolific research and writing and
plays and speeches and newspaper
editorials and so forth a big part of
what he focused on was the findings that
he continued to show which showed that
racial stratification was this problem
of the 20th century and the problem of
the color line and that when he talked
about racial stratification Du Bois was
very incisive and very thorough and very
in-depth and making points about how
racial stratification was not simply
something that was subject to personal
opinions or ideas or beliefs rather it
was very systemic and it was very
structural and was codified into law
culture education housing public policy
virtually every segment and every social
institution in American life was defined
by systemic and institutionalized racial
disparities that perpetuated racial
inequalities for various groups and Du
Bois is very clear in his writing that
this represents an American failure but
at least in a lot of his early writings
before he just got completely frustrated
and quit America and moved to Ghana and
decided he was done with it all in more
of his optimistic days he wrote that
more importantly this indicated a system
that could be changed in other words his
belief during a large part of his time
in a mirror
was that with clear sound scholarship
that drew attention to the ways in which
racial disparities were socially
constructed and a part of
institutionalized functions that
individuals brought to bear there were
ways if we could understand the roots of
this problem to dismantle this problem
and this is important for a number of
reasons not only for establishing Du
Bois as role in the pantheon of American
sociology and in scholarly work but also
for thinking about how systems of racial
stratification in forms work and informs
the ways in which labor markets and
processes of structuring work in
workplaces are done in ways that really
reflect these ideas of race and
inequality this is important because
this allows us to move past a lot of the
stereotypes that I think often structure
and shape the way that people make
decisions about work and also that
people make decisions about their own
lives and experiences in ways that
inhabit them at excuse me inhibit the
maximization of human capital and all
that really means is a fancy way of
saying what Dubois said more simply and
more concisely and clearly that I could
which was simply that if we continue to
have a society which is founded on these
ideas about racial inequality and that
persists in establishing these
institutionalized forms of racial
discrimination ultimately we all lose
and we really do ourselves a disservice
as a society because we are limiting and
minimizing the potential that everybody
has to be fully contributing members of
society if we insist on having a society
that's grounded in racial stratification
in educational systems in workplaces in
reproducing wealth inequalities that may
seem on a superficial level to feel good
for some of us but ultimately we deprive
ourselves of doctors of teachers of
attorneys of CPAs if people who could be
contributing to society in various ways
but are not being permitted to do so
simply because of their racial
background and so I argue that when we
think about this in lines of Du Bois as
arguments and when we're mindful of the
ways in which racial stratification is
present in shaping our social
institutions and the ways that that also
affects our workplaces that helps us to
give rise to the sorts of processes that
Bulai a lot of the assumptions that we
have about why outcomes look the way
that they do and we can think about this
in terms of some of the stereotypes
people often marshal to try to explain
why disparities exist in workplaces and
other social institutions the idea that
I'm sure all of us have heard various
iterations of these sorts of stereotypes
and generalizations that if blacks
weren't so lazy they could get ahead
right if life people simply stopped
asking for handouts and just we're
willing to work harder and we're willing
to follow the rules then equal
opportunity would simply follow or
arguments that Asian Americans succeed
because of their cultural values and
that they simply do follow this model
minority path of working hard and
following the rules and that that leads
to achievement or for white Americans
the idea that I'm white no one ever gave
me anything I've succeeded because of my
own merits and because of my own hard
work and that I have earned and deserve
all the things that I have what research
shows us particularly sociological
research shows us is that if we're
thinking about outcomes that occur in
workplaces in labor markets clearly none
of these statements are really
completely grounded in fact most of
these are gross misrepresentations and
the fact that these stereotypes and
ideas often become part of all cultural
toolkit that we use to understand why
racial disparities exist simply points
more to the need for and the importance
of research on race that shows how
processes differently impact various
groups leading us into different
outcomes in labor markets and workplaces
so there are important insights from
research that really speak to this both
in terms of Du Bois as research in the
ways that it's present in the current
age so just to give a little bit of
history and background into some of the
arguments that Du Bois found in his work
he noted in doing research on and in his
book the Philadelphia Negro that blacks
were concentrated in low-wage low status
jobs and they often did not have the
educational training or credentials to
qualify them for other work and when
they did explicit discrimination made it
very hard to get or keep these sorts of
jobs importantly Du Bois argue that this
was a real contrast to a lot of the
prevailing wisdom of the time in many
cases people would look at racial
disparities that existed in workplaces
and simply say well if there's under
representation of black workers in these
sorts of high status jobs it's obviously
because they're apathetic or they are
indifferent or they're lazy or they just
don't want to work they don't want to be
in high status while paying jobs they'd
simply rather work as Porter's or
sharecroppers or domestic work because
that's just what they like doing right
and so ultimately we have a
system that works for everybody because
blacks don't have to tax themselves with
difficult things like thinking and
progress and advancement because they
can just stay in their lane and enjoy
doing this sort of low-wage labor that
they enjoy right Du Bois points out
something that might sound pretty basic
to us today in 2018 but was actually
very groundbreaking at the time which
was the argument that these inequalities
stemmed from structural barriers in
educational systems and in labor markets
that this was not necessarily that this
was not a an outcome that we could
simply attribute to black workers and
harun inferiority or their laziness or
their character traits these were these
inequalities and these disparities were
a clearly defined result of systemic
processes that channeled black workers
into certain occupations and excluded
them from others what do we find when we
look at the research that exists today
I'll talk a little bit about some of the
basic summaries of research from
sociologists and people from other
fields that talks about how
unfortunately while unquestionably there
has been progress a lot of the findings
that Du Bois articulated in the
Philadelphia Negro in some of his later
work still have some aspects that are
present today when we think about how
these processes how these social
processes define workplace outcomes for
working class blacks research shows that
many of the patterns that Dubois
identifies during his writing pretty
much remain the same in William Julius
Wilson classic book the truly
disadvantaged he spends a lot of time
identifying how racial and economic
social dislocation constrains access to
work what he means here is to make the
argument that in the post-civil rights
era when we see black Americans
concentrated in urban areas that are
often underserved by educational
institutions by workplaces by other
social institutions that offer a bridge
to other broader parts of society this
has serious consequences for those who
he deems the truly disadvantaged and who
he describes as being part of the urban
underclass for these black Americans
simply living in areas where work no
longer thrives in its present means that
they are automatically put in a position
where they are differently advantaged or
specifically disadvantaged when it comes
to having access to an opportunities for
gainful employment and Wilson's argument
is more complicated than that but the
gist of his point here for what this
means for our purposes is that we're
thinking about
challenges that working class blacks
experience a lot of the spatial
dislocation that Dubois identified
during the turn of the century still
continues and persists and remains
present for black Americans in these
environments in ways that have adverse
consequences for their workplace options
sociologist Deirdre Royster makes the
argument that for working-class blacks
in particular social networks do not
always produce employment access and
I'll talk a lot more about this in a few
slides
but the point that she makes here is
that particularly in a more modern day
work environment when people generate
many of their access to job leads and
information about jobs and access to
jobs through our connect through their
connections we all know the statement
that it's not who you know it's not what
you know it's who you know
and that these networks and connections
are critical for offering us advancement
into jobs particularly jobs that offer
some sort of economic and social
mobility for working-class black
Americans these networks are often
largely either not available or not
available in ways that lead to this sort
of advancement and sociologist Ivy Ken
points out that for black women in
particular there are gender dimensions
to the experiences that they have in
labor markets and workplaces they're
often stereotyped as unreliable single
mothers and of course these stereotypes
preclude whether or not they are either
single or mothers it doesn't matter that
the women in question may be married
they may not be mothers they may be
married mothers with stable family
arrangements employers preconceptions
are that as black women they are likely
to be low income they're likely to be
unreliable they're likely to be single
mothers who will have family issues and
arrangements that will preclude them
from being the sorts of workers that
employers value so we know for example
that for working class blacks a lot of
the challenges that Dubois points to are
still pretty prevalent and remain the
same for black professionals and this is
where I've concentrated most of the bulk
of my own research the issues that come
out are a little bit different and this
is an interesting contrast to some of
Dubois as points because by virtue of
the time period in which she was writing
a lot of his focus on black Americans
focused on them being segregated in a
certain concentrations or certain areas
in certain concentrations in ways that
are still present today but put him in a
position at I'm period in and in a
position where he missed some of the
emergence of their growing black middle
class that was prevalent during
the 90s and 2000's and has met with
limited continued mobility since then
but the point here is that when we look
at black professionals and we think
about ways that race is significant and
matters different patterns emerge among
this group and a study that I did of
black men working in predominantly white
male dominated jobs to try to understand
how intersections of gender and race had
an impact on their experiences in the
minority one of the most interesting
findings that came out of this study was
my finding that for many black men
racial discrimination informed their
relationships with women and what I
found was that many black men in working
in these types of jobs drew from
positions where they felt somewhat
integrated into the organizational
structure but not completely fully
assimilated and what that meant was that
they recognized that gender offered them
some privileges in the extent that they
could fit in with most of their mostly
white male co-workers and that they
could bond based on their shared
gendered experiences but they also were
very cognizant of the racial
discrimination that they encountered and
feeling as though they were still racial
minorities in this work what this meant
was that when they related to their
women co-workers who were usually also
in the minority this gave them a sense
of feeling as though they shared a
certain type of common ground with many
of their women counterparts this was not
to say that they assumed that their
experiences were completely the same as
their women co-workers but they were
likely to say to me I understand the
ways that people are treating women in
this organization because it parallels
the sorts of treatment and experiences
that I've had as a black man so I see
the types of things that my male
co-workers say about women I understand
that there's this assumption that women
are not going to be able to cut it in
medicine or law and the people who are
making these assumptions based on
stereotypes based on misrepresentations
and misjudgments I don't like seeing
that because that's what also happens to
me but men also recognize that because
of their position as men in the
organization their gender advantages put
them in a position where in some cases
there were things that they could do to
try to create more equitable playing
fields for their women counterparts they
talked specifically about wanting to
take specific efforts to engage in
mentoring to try to work with women to
try to offer a different model of
masculinity to dispel the sorts of
stereotypes and behaviors that they saw
among many of their white male
counterparts so here we have a bit of a
different picture of how race is having
an impact on
working in these professions and ways
that show that it is informed not just
by race but by the ways that race and
gender and class intersect for men in
these higher status occupations I've
also found in a current project that's
worth coming next year that for black
professionals perceptions of
discrimination vary significantly by
class and this is a study that I've been
working on of black healthcare workers
and what we think of as the new economy
and I've been trying to think about ways
that changes to the way that we work and
how we work and how those changes
reflect technological social and
ideological changes over time have had
an impact on black professionals in
other words how does the way that work
has changed have an impact on black
professionals and one of the things that
I found from this project is that for
black healthcare workers who are the
focus of my study for blacks working in
the highest status fields in the
healthcare industry which I argue our
medicine there's a perception that
racial discrimination is much more
grounded in structural processes than it
is an everyday overt interpersonal
experiences this was not true for
workers who were lower in the
Occupational hierarchy and the
healthcare industry technicians and
particularly nurses were much more
likely to talk about experiencing racial
discrimination as a more interpersonal
daily / consistent sort of barrage of
what we might think of as
microaggressions but ultimately what we
see here is that when we're talking
about black Americans it's important to
emphasize that this is not a monolithic
one-size-fits-all group but there are a
lot of variations there are a lot of
differences and that these differences
have impacts for perceptions of and
responses to perceived discrimination
and finally I'll reference the work of
John Williams's a law professor who
makes the point that again when we're
thinking about these gendered issues for
black women advice to lean in and to
simply be more assertive and to not
leave before you leave and all the other
things that are mentioned in Sheryl
Sandberg's book are not quite so useful
for women of color and for black women
in particular black women have a noted
history and noted evidence and research
of leaning in of being ambitious of
having aspirations that far exceed where
they are generally represented in
organizations but when black women lean
in it turns into 2006 and Fat Joe and
the Terror Squad and everybody who leans
back it's not the same it's just not the
same reaction when black women are
engaging in
this process so again this is important
for thinking of how race and race has to
be understood as a process that is
informed and structured by gender and
class and other factors in critical and
important ways that have specific
outcomes I think it's also important
when we're talking about race at work to
remember that it's easy to some degree
in common to think about how race has an
impact on black Americans it is also
useful to think about the active role
that whites play in shaping and
maintaining workplace discrimination
Nancy de Tomaso argues that whites rely
very heavily on social networks for
hiring and mobility as I mentioned
before but when these networks that
whites use are predominantly white then
this leads to opportunity hoarding in
other words if there's a common practice
in place where whites where people find
jobs by referencing or by referring
colleagues or friends or people in their
neighborhood or what have you on the
face of it this seems very benign and it
seems very commonplace but if your
friendship circles are 76% white as we
know from research most whites are
likely to have exclusively white social
groups if your neighborhoods are
predominantly white which we know racial
segregation means is likely the case
then simply referring people to people
that you know for job positions isn't
just a way of doing a favor and I think
that one of the previous presenter
presenters alluded to this in her in her
her presentation this isn't just a way
of doing a favor this is a way of doing
a favor that perpetuates inequality and
it allows colorblind racism to pursue
persist Laura and Rivera shows that
upper-class whites are likely to
leverage cultural accuse to access elite
professional service work in other words
again in terms of having access to jobs
references to certain types of social
cues and indicators like playing squash
or lacrosse rather than football or
basketball serve as cues to hiring
managers that these are people who are
familiar and comfortable and people that
they should employ hiring managers are
also shown to explicitly prefer white
workers I just simply state this when it
comes to making decisions about hiring
and that this is not just black and
white
asian-americans are more highly educated
but see fewer economic returns to the
work that they do which means that even
though they are more likely to have
higher levels of education than many
other racial groups this does not
transform into commensurate returns on
education
Syrio types of passivity
heard asian-american men in particular
as they are seen to not necessarily have
the leadership skills and capabilities
for particularly high status culturally
masculinized jobs and Latinos encounter
racial stereotypes of being of other
nests and of lacking qualifications
particularly the intelligence for the
same type of high status work in other
words structural barriers were present
for other groups besides blacks and it's
important particularly as racial
demographics change in the United States
to be mindful of how when we were
talking about issues related to race and
gender and leadership and work to be
thoughtful about the ways that this has
parallel but often distinctive
manifestations for various groups so in
summary I'll conclude just by linking
this back to the arguments that Du Bois
made and the importance of thinking
about researching race and why it's
necessary in a broad context researching
race highlights that racial patterns and
racial stratification creates workplace
disparities but importantly I think it's
useful to emphasize that just as these
disparities are things that aren't
natural these aren't unavoidable these
aren't inevitable these are things that
were created in that they can that can
be fixed and then attention to
structural inequalities helps to dispel
the stereotypes that maintain
stratification it helps us to move away
from this thinking that people operate
in a completely colorblind meritocracy
where everybody earns their advantages
on their own or if they are not
advantaged are not advantaged because
they simply didn't try hard enough or
work hard enough enough research
highlights the ways that social
structures can be changed and doing so
has the potential to benefit all through
the more productive use of human capital
by making sure that these sorts of
barriers are not in place and by
researching these barriers so that we
know what they are and how they got
there and how they are problematic this
puts us in a better position for making
sure that we are eradicating these
barriers so that we are maximizing
everyone's potential to contribute fully
and completely to our society thank you
[Applause]
